originalTitle: Rwanda takes legal action against UK over axed migrant deal
title: Rwanda takes legal action against UK over axed migrant deal
content: The African nation argues it is owed payments but Downing Street says it will fight the case.

originalTitle: France invites Chad president in bid to ease troubled relations
title: France invites Chad president in bid to ease troubled relations
content: Franco-Chadian military relations have been strained after Chad abruptly ended its defence agreement with France.

originalTitle: Nigerian officers to face trial over coup-plot allegations
title: Big News from Nigeria: A Story About Rules and Fairness!
content:
Hello from Africa!

Jambo, my amazing friends! That means hello in Swahili. I'm your special kid-friendly news reporter, bringing you exciting stories from our wonderful continent, Africa! Today, we're going on an adventure to a very big country called Nigeria. It's in West Africa. Get ready to learn about something important!

What's Happening in Nigeria?

Imagine your class. You have a teacher, right? And maybe a class captain. They help lead the class. Well, a country also has leaders. In Nigeria, there's a leader called the President. His name is President Bola Tinubu. He helps run the whole country. Now, some people who work for the country, like some officers from the army, are in the news. An "officer" is someone who has an important job in the army or police. They wear uniforms and help keep people safe. But here's the big news: some of these officers are going to a special place called a court.

Who is the President?

The President is like the head of a very, very big family – the country! People in Nigeria voted for President Bola Tinubu. This means they chose him to be their leader. He works very hard to make Nigeria a good place for everyone. He helps make sure there are schools, hospitals, and good roads. When people vote, it's a fair way to choose who leads. Everyone gets to say who they want. This is a very important part of how countries work. It's called "democracy." **Did you know?** Nigeria is a really big country! It has more people than any other country in Africa. Wow!

What is a "Coup"? (Simple Explanation)

This word "coup" sounds a bit tricky, but let's make it simple. Imagine you are playing a game with your friends, and you all agreed on the rules and who is the leader. But then, one friend suddenly says, "No, I don't like this leader, I want to be the leader now!" And they try to take over the game without anyone else agreeing. That's a bit like a "coup." It's when a small group of people try to take power from the President and the government *without* people voting for them. They try to do it secretly or by using force. But this is not allowed. It goes against the rules of the country and against what the people want. The officers we are talking about are "accused" of planning one of these secret takeovers. "Accused" means someone says they did it, but it's not proven yet.

What is an "Investigation"?

When something big happens, like someone says these officers made a secret plan, clever people need to find out what really happened. This is called an an "investigation." It's like being a detective! They ask questions, they look for clues, and they gather information. For a long time last year, people were looking very carefully into this situation. They wanted to understand everything. Some officers were "detained" during this time. "Detained" means they were asked to stay in a special place while the investigation was happening, so they couldn't go anywhere. This investigation helps everyone understand the truth. It's like when your teacher finds out who broke the crayon – they ask questions and look for clues!

What is a "Trial" or "Court"?

After the investigation, if there are enough clues, people go to a "trial." A trial happens in a "court." A court is a very important building where a special person called a judge listens to everyone. The judge's job is to make sure everything is fair. In a trial, the people who say the officers did something wrong will show their clues. And the officers, or their helpers, will get to tell their side of the story too. They will say if they think the accusations are true or not. Then, the judge will think about all the clues and all the stories. And finally, the judge will decide if the officers did something wrong or not. This is how justice works! It's about being fair to everyone. **Did you know?** In Nigeria, just like many places, everyone is innocent until proven guilty in court! This means we believe they are innocent until the judge says they are not.

Why are Rules Important?

Just like in your classroom, countries have rules. These rules are called laws. Laws help everyone live together safely and happily. If people just did whatever they wanted, things could get very messy! When people try to take power without following the rules, it can make things unstable. It can make people scared. That's why it's so important that when someone is accused of breaking a big rule like planning a "coup," we have a fair system to check it out. The court system is there to protect the rules and keep everyone safe. It shows that Nigeria believes in its rules and wants to make sure everyone, even important officers, follows them.

Did you know about Nigeria?

Nigeria is a country full of amazing things! * It has beautiful beaches along the Atlantic Ocean. * It has a very rich culture with many different languages and traditions. * Nigerian music and movies are famous all over Africa and beyond! * The capital city of Nigeria is called Abuja. It's a wonderful place with wonderful people, and they all want their country to be peaceful and follow the rules that they all agreed upon.

What Happens Next?

Now, these officers will go to court. They will have their chance to speak. The judge will listen very carefully to everything. It might take some time, but that's okay. It's important to be thorough and fair. The important thing is that Nigeria is using its rules and its courts to solve this problem. This shows that the country is strong and believes in a fair way to handle things. Everyone will be watching to see what the court decides.

Staying Strong in Africa!

So, there you have it, my curious friends! A big story from Nigeria, explained in simple words. It's all about following the rules, having fair investigations, and using courts to find the truth. Our African countries are always working hard to be strong, fair, and safe places for all of us. Keep learning and asking questions! Until next time, kwaheri! That means goodbye!
summary: Some officers in Nigeria are going to a special court because they are accused of planning to secretly take power from President Bola Tinubu, and the court will find out what really happened.
whyMatters: This news is important because it shows that Nigeria follows its own rules and uses a fair system, like courts, to solve big problems. It teaches us that everyone, even important people, must follow the rules to keep the country safe and stable.

title: Sweden aims to lower age of criminal responsibility to 13 as gangs recruit children
content: Critics say the proposal could see even younger children becoming offenders as well as breaching children's rights.

originalTitle: Guardiola apologises to ref Hallam but 'defends' outburst
title: Guardiola apologises to ref Hallam but 'defends' outburst
content: Pep Guardiola has apologised to new Premier League referee Farai Hallam if he "feels offended", having taken issue with the official following Manchester City's victory over Wolves on Saturday. But the Spaniard said he has to "defend my club and my players".
